com.edugility.splain
Class MessageFactory<T>

java.lang.Object
  com.edugility.splain.MessageFactory<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of Object used by the getMessage(List) method; the type of Object used by the Patterns that help select messages
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class MessageFactory<T>
extends Object
implements Serializable

A factory for localized messages appropriate for object graphs.

To use a MessageFactory, create a new instance and add Patterns to it. Then pass a List of items to the getMessage(List) method.

This class is not safe for concurrent use by multiple Threads.

Author:
Laird Nelson
See Also:
getMessage(List), Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

MessageFactory

public MessageFactory()
Creates a new MessageFactory.

Method Detail

addPattern

public final Set<Pattern<T>> addPattern(ResourceBundleKey key,
                                        Pattern<T> pattern)
Adds a Pattern to the Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied ResourceBundleKey and returns the full Set of such Patterns. If no such Set exists, one is created whose sole contents are the supplied Pattern.

This method never returns null.

Patterns may also be added by retrieving a Set of Patterns and adding a Pattern to it directly.

Parameters:
key - the ResourceBundleKey under which the supplied Pattern is to be indexed; must not be null
pattern - the Pattern to add; must not be null
Returns:
the full Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied key; never null
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if key or pattern is null
See Also:
Pattern, ResourceBundleKey, addPatterns(ResourceBundleKey, Iterable), getPatterns(ResourceBundleKey)

addPatterns

public Set<Pattern<T>> addPatterns(ResourceBundleKey key,
                                   Iterable<Pattern<T>> patterns)
Adds the supplied Iterable of Patterns to the Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied key and returns the full Set of such Patterns that results from this addition.

Patterns may also be added by retrieving a Set of Patterns and adding a Pattern to it directly.

This method never returns null.

Parameters:
key - the ResourceBundleKey under which the Pattern is to be stored; must not be null
patterns - an Iterable of Patterns to add; no references are kept to this object; must not be null
Returns:
the full Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied key; never null
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if either parameter is null
See Also:
Pattern, ResourceBundleKey, getPatterns(ResourceBundleKey)

getPatterns

public Set<Pattern<T>> getPatterns(ResourceBundleKey key)
Returns a Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied key, or null if there is no such Set.

The Set that is returned is the actual Set used internally by this MessageFactory and is mutable.

This method may return null.

Parameters:
key - the ResourceBundleKey whose Patterns are to be retrieved; must not be null
Returns:
a Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied key, or null
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if key is null

removePatterns

public Set<Pattern<T>> removePatterns(ResourceBundleKey key)
Removes the Set of Patterns indexed under the supplied key and returns it.

This method may return null.

Parameters:
key - a ResourceBundleKey whose associated Patterns are to be removed; must not be null
Returns:
a Set of Patterns that was removed, or null
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if key was null

format

protected Object format(Object rawMessage,
                        Matcher<T> matcher)
Formats or transforms the supplied rawMessage Object in some way, perhaps by using the information stored as part of the supplied Matcher, and returns the formatted or transformed Object.

This implementation checks to see if the supplied rawMessage is an instance of CharSequence. If so, it is treated as an MVEL template. The template is interpolated using all the capture groups and variables that the supplied Matcher is capable of providing.

Specifically, orb tags may have bodies that reference the variables contained by the supplied Matcher, as well as its capture groups. Capture group variable references begin with the $ character, so the following orb tag would return a List representing the full match:

@{$0}

Parameters:
rawMessage - the unformatted message as returned by the getMessage(List) method; may be null
matcher - the Matcher that was used by the getMessage(List) method in producing the rawMessage parameter value; may be null
Returns:
a formatted version of the supplied rawMessage, which may simply be the supplied rawMessage if no formatting could be performed
See Also:
TemplateRuntime, getMessage(List)

getMessage

public String getMessage(List<T> input)
Given a List of Objects of type T, matches that List against all the Patterns that have been added to this MessageFactory in insertion order, and, when one of them has a match, selects and formats the associated key, converts it to a String and returns the result.

This method may return null.

Parameters:
input - the List of Objects of type T to match; may be null
Returns:
a converted and formatted message, or null
See Also:
convert(Object), format(Object, Matcher)

convert

protected String convert(Object object)
Converts the supplied Object into a String. The default implementation of this method returns null if the supplied Object is null, or the result of invoking Object.toString() on it if it is not.

This method may return null.

Parameters:
object - the Object to convert; may be null
Returns:
a String that is the result of converting the supplied Object, or null

getMessage

public String getMessage(List<T> input,
                         String defaultValue)
Calls getMessage(List), and if the return value is null, returns the supplied defaultValue parameter as the return value instead.

This method may return null.

This method suppresses any MissingResourceExceptions thrown by getMessage(List) and returns the supplied defaultValue parameter in such cases.

Returns:
a formatted message, or the defaultValue parameter, or null if the defaultValue parameter is null itself
